trans-unit.source: Remote Desktop Gateway and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server using RADIUS
trans-unit.target: Remote Desktop Gateway and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server using RADIUS

trans-unit.source: This is the Azure Multi-factor authentication page that will assist in deploying Remote Desktop (RD) Gateway and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server using RADIUS.
trans-unit.target: This is the Azure Multi-factor authentication page that will assist in deploying Remote Desktop (RD) Gateway and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server using RADIUS.

trans-unit.source: Remote Desktop Gateway and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server using RADIUS
trans-unit.target: Remote Desktop Gateway and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server using RADIUS

trans-unit.source: In many cases, Remote Desktop Gateway uses the local NPS to authenticate users.
trans-unit.target: In many cases, Remote Desktop Gateway uses the local NPS to authenticate users.

trans-unit.source: This document describes how to route RADIUS request out from the Remote Desktop Gateway (through the local NPS) to the Multi-Factor Authentication Server.
trans-unit.target: This document describes how to route RADIUS request out from the Remote Desktop Gateway (through the local NPS) to the Multi-Factor Authentication Server.

trans-unit.source: The Multi-Factor Authentication Server should be installed on a separate server, which will then proxy the RADIUS request back to the NPS on the Remote Desktop Gateway Server.
trans-unit.target: The Multi-Factor Authentication Server should be installed on a separate server, which will then proxy the RADIUS request back to the NPS on the Remote Desktop Gateway Server.

trans-unit.source: After NPS validates the username and password, it will return a response to the Multi-Factor Authentication Server which performs the second factor of authentication before returning a result to the gateway.
trans-unit.target: After NPS validates the username and password, it will return a response to the Multi-Factor Authentication Server which performs the second factor of authentication before returning a result to the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Configure the RD Gateway
trans-unit.target: Configure the RD Gateway

trans-unit.source: The RD Gateway must be configured to send RADIUS authentication to an Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server.
trans-unit.target: The RD Gateway must be configured to send RADIUS authentication to an Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server.

trans-unit.source: Once RD Gateway has been installed, configured and is working, go into the RD Gateway properties.
trans-unit.target: Once RD Gateway has been installed, configured and is working, go into the RD Gateway properties.

trans-unit.source: Go to the RD CAP Store tab and change it to use a Central server running NPS instead of Local server running NPS.
trans-unit.target: Go to the RD CAP Store tab and change it to use a Central server running NPS instead of Local server running NPS.

trans-unit.source: Add one or more Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Servers as RADIUS servers and specify a shared secret for each server.
trans-unit.target: Add one or more Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Servers as RADIUS servers and specify a shared secret for each server.

trans-unit.source: Configure NPS
trans-unit.target: Configure NPS

trans-unit.source: The RD Gateway uses NPS to send the RADIUS request to Azure Multi-Factor Authentication.
trans-unit.target: The RD Gateway uses NPS to send the RADIUS request to Azure Multi-Factor Authentication.

trans-unit.source: A timeout must be changed to prevent the RD Gateway from timing out before multi-factor authentication has completed.
trans-unit.target: A timeout must be changed to prevent the RD Gateway from timing out before multi-factor authentication has completed.

trans-unit.source: Use the following procedure to configure NPS.
trans-unit.target: Use the following procedure to configure NPS.

trans-unit.source: In NPS, expand the RADIUS Clients and Server menu in the left column and click on Remote RADIUS Server Groups.
trans-unit.target: In NPS, expand the RADIUS Clients and Server menu in the left column and click on Remote RADIUS Server Groups.

trans-unit.source: Go into the properties of the TS GATEWAY SERVER GROUP.
trans-unit.target: Go into the properties of the TS GATEWAY SERVER GROUP.

trans-unit.source: Edit the RADIUS Server(s) displayed and go to the Load Balancing tab.
trans-unit.target: Edit the RADIUS Server(s) displayed and go to the Load Balancing tab.

trans-unit.source: Change the “Number of seconds without response before request is considered dropped” and the “Number of seconds between requests when server is identified as unavailable” to 30-60 seconds.
trans-unit.target: Change the “Number of seconds without response before request is considered dropped” and the “Number of seconds between requests when server is identified as unavailable” to 30-60 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Authentication/Account tab and ensure that the RADIUS ports specified match the ports that the Multi-Factor Authentication Server will be listening on.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Authentication/Account tab and ensure that the RADIUS ports specified match the ports that the Multi-Factor Authentication Server will be listening on.

trans-unit.source: NPS must also be configured to receive RADIUS authentications back from the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server.
trans-unit.target: NPS must also be configured to receive RADIUS authentications back from the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server.

trans-unit.source: Click on RADIUS Clients in the left menu.
trans-unit.target: Click on RADIUS Clients in the left menu.

trans-unit.source: Add the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server as a RADIUS client.
trans-unit.target: Add the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server as a RADIUS client.

trans-unit.source: Choose a Friendly name and specify a shared secret.
trans-unit.target: Choose a Friendly name and specify a shared secret.

trans-unit.source: Expand the Policies section in the left navigation and click on Connection Request Policies.
trans-unit.target: Expand the Policies section in the left navigation and click on Connection Request Policies.

trans-unit.source: It should contain a Connection Request Policy called TS GATEWAY AUTHORIZATION POLICY that was created when RD Gateway was configured.
trans-unit.target: It should contain a Connection Request Policy called TS GATEWAY AUTHORIZATION POLICY that was created when RD Gateway was configured.

trans-unit.source: This policy forwards RADIUS requests to the Multi-Factor Authentication Server.
trans-unit.target: This policy forwards RADIUS requests to the Multi-Factor Authentication Server.

trans-unit.source: Copy this policy to create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Copy this policy to create a new one.

trans-unit.source: In the new policy, add a condition that matches the Client Friendly Name with the Friendly name set in step 2 above for the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server RADIUS client.
trans-unit.target: In the new policy, add a condition that matches the Client Friendly Name with the Friendly name set in step 2 above for the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server RADIUS client.

trans-unit.source: Change the Authentication Provider to Local Computer.
trans-unit.target: Change the Authentication Provider to Local Computer.

trans-unit.source: This policy ensures that when a RADIUS request is received from the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server, the authentication occurs locally instead of sending a RADIUS request back to the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server which would result in a loop condition.
trans-unit.target: This policy ensures that when a RADIUS request is received from the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server, the authentication occurs locally instead of sending a RADIUS request back to the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server which would result in a loop condition.

trans-unit.source: To prevent the loop condition, this new policy must be ordered ABOVE the original policy that forwards to the Multi-Factor Authentication Server.
trans-unit.target: To prevent the loop condition, this new policy must be ordered ABOVE the original policy that forwards to the Multi-Factor Authentication Server.

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure Multi-Factor Authentication
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure Multi-Factor Authentication

trans-unit.source: The Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server is configured as a RADIUS proxy between RD Gateway and NPS.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server is configured as a RADIUS proxy between RD Gateway and NPS.

trans-unit.source: It should be installed on a domain-joined server that is separate from the RD Gateway server.
trans-unit.target: It should be installed on a domain-joined server that is separate from the RD Gateway server.

trans-unit.source: Use the following procedure to configure the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server.
trans-unit.target: Use the following procedure to configure the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server.

trans-unit.source: Open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server and click the RADIUS Authentication icon.
trans-unit.target: Open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server and click the RADIUS Authentication icon.

trans-unit.source: Check the Enable RADIUS authentication checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Check the Enable RADIUS authentication checkbox.

trans-unit.source: On the Clients tab, ensure the ports match what is configured in NPS and click the Add…
trans-unit.target: On the Clients tab, ensure the ports match what is configured in NPS and click the Add…

trans-unit.source: button.
trans-unit.target: button.

trans-unit.source: Add the RD Gateway server IP address, application name (optional) and a shared secret.
trans-unit.target: Add the RD Gateway server IP address, application name (optional) and a shared secret.

trans-unit.source: The shared secret will need to be the same on both the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server and RD Gateway.
trans-unit.target: The shared secret will need to be the same on both the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server and RD Gateway.

trans-unit.source: Click the Target tab and choose the RADIUS server(s) radio button.
trans-unit.target: Click the Target tab and choose the RADIUS server(s) radio button.

trans-unit.source: Click the Add…
trans-unit.target: Click the Add…

trans-unit.source: button.
trans-unit.target: button.

trans-unit.source: Enter the IP address, shared secret and ports of the NPS server.
trans-unit.target: Enter the IP address, shared secret and ports of the NPS server.

trans-unit.source: Unless using a central NPS, the RADIUS client and RADIUS target will be the same.
trans-unit.target: Unless using a central NPS, the RADIUS client and RADIUS target will be the same.

trans-unit.source: The shared secret must match the one setup in the RADIUS client section of the NPS server.
trans-unit.target: The shared secret must match the one setup in the RADIUS client section of the NPS server.

trans-unit.source: Radius Authentication
trans-unit.target: Radius Authentication
